response.answer_text: Building upon Franklin's work, many other scientists studied electricity and began to understand more about how it works. For example, in 1879, Thomas Edison invented the electric light bulb and our world has been brighter ever since! But was Benjamin Franklin really the first person to discover electricity? In 1878, Edison formed the Edison Electric Light Company in New York City with several financiers, including J. P. Morgan, Spencer Trask, and the members of the Vanderbilt family. Edison made the first public demonstration of his incandescent light bulb on December 31, 1879, in Menlo Park.

Because of it's very makeup and nature, electricity was rather “discovered” not invented, with its litany of brilliant contributors standing each others' shoulders and spanning centuries. There's a much misconstrued story that can be found in many American history books that credits Ben Franklin with the discovery in electricity. While he did not discover electricity, his key, kite and Strom experiment did prove that “lightning” and “electric Sparks" are, essentially, the same thing. In 1831, Michael Faraday, the great British scientist, made electricity an integral part of construction of his electric dynamo--the first of it's kind. Closer to our times, the great Thomas Edison is credited with inventing Direct Current (DC) and Nikola Tesla is credited with inventing Alternating Current (AC). I hope this very brief answer helps.

Electricity was not invented. It is a natural phenomenon which has always been here, and can be felt or seen in the static buildup of charge in our dry hair, in the lightning, and in the Northern Lights.
Electricity was “invented” a nanosecond after the big bang.
Being a naturally occuring phenomenon it was never invented
